title: The Story Behind My Website – Blog
desc: A blog post about why and how my personal website was built – from the first version to structure, pages, statistics, and next steps.
h1: The Story Behind My Personal Website
lead: Why I built it, how it evolved, and what it tries to do "right" (spoiler: structure + documentation - noise).

tldr.title: TL;DR
list: The website started as a place to gather CV + projects in one place (and avoid the "where is that now?"-trap).
It quickly evolved into a small system: Portfolio, Resources/Downloads, and a Blog for notes.
I built statistics pages (course stats and training stats) to show progression rather than just claims.
The goal is to make things easy to find: fewer clicks, clear navigation, and documentable content.

why.title: Why build a personal website at all?
why.p1: I've always had a fairly classic challenge: many projects, many files, many versions. And when you work with study projects, code, teaching materials, and a CV, "link chaos" quickly becomes a reality.
why.p2: So the idea was actually simple and a bit old-school: one place that I own, where the most important things live. Not just a profile — but a structured base where I can update things continuously without having to reinvent everything every time.

build.title: How it was built (without making it unnecessarily fancy)
build.intro: I chose a "keep it clean" approach: pure HTML/CSS, a clear navbar, and reusable cards for content. It sounds simple — but that's exactly what makes it maintainable.

p1.title: Principle 1: Structure over aesthetics
p1.text: If the navigation is logical, the site can look 20% less "fancy" and still be 10x more useful.

p2.title: Principle 2: It must be extensible
p2.text: New pages (courses, certs, notes, media) must be plug-and-play: same layout, same footer, same style.

p3.title: Principle 3: Documentation beats vibe
p3.text: That's why the statistics pages became a thing. It's hard to argue against data when it's presented clearly.

timeline.title: Timeline: from "CV page" to mini-portfolio
list: Version 2: Portfolio with projects + cases. (The extra mile.)
Version 3: Resources/Downloads. (Tools I use myself and can share.)
Version 4: Blog with three tracks: professional, training, travel.
Version 5: Statistics pages: course evaluations and training data. (Progression, not just words.)
Now: Multiple sub-pages under CV (skills, experience, courses, certs) + "Press/Media".
timeline.outro: And yes — some of it sounds like "overkill". But when you update often, structure suddenly becomes a superpower.

enables.title: What the website enables (that LinkedIn doesn't do as well)
list: Long-form: explanations, notes, and reflections without being trapped in a feed format.
Artifacts: downloads, templates, code examples, and how-to's in a fixed structure.
Dashboards: statistics pages that can be updated continuously and show development over time.
Control: layout, language (DA/EN), and what is highlighted where.

next.title: Next Steps
next.text: The most obvious next upgrade is to make the blog more robust: either with more individual posts (like this page) or a simple tag system. Additionally, it makes sense to expand the CV section further into dedicated sub-pages to keep the main CV from becoming a wall of text.

feedback.title: Do you have feedback?
feedback.text: If you find something hard to find, or if you have suggestions for a page that's missing, please let me know. I try to optimize this website as a tool — not just a brochure.
